item.title: U.S. Charges New Suspect in Haiti President’s Murder, Widening Investigation
description: The case could help U.S. prosecutors get closer to the people who plotted the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti.

description.__text: The funeral of President Jovenel Moïse in July.

credit.__text: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: U.N. Approves Israeli Measure to Condemn Holocaust Denial
description: The resolution was aimed at combating what Israel and other countries have described as an epidemic of disinformation about the murder of nearly six million Jews and millions of others by the Nazis.

description.__text: The ‘Hall of Names’ at the Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial museum on the eve of Holocaust Remembrance Day last year in Jerusalem.

item.title: A Trove of Old Photos Could Reveal the Future of These Arctic Glaciers
description: The Svalbard Islands, part of Norway, are warming seven times faster than the global average. Aerial pictures from the 1930s are helping researchers understand what that means for the region’s ice.

item.title: In Peru, Courts ‘Used Like Whips’ to Silence Journalists
description: The author of a book about a powerful politician has been sentenced to two years in prison. Media advocates say the case is part of a trend in which the courts are being used to punish critics.

description.__text: The Peruvian journalist Christopher Acosta has been sentenced to two years in prison and, with his publisher, fined $100,000 following a defamation lawsuit brought by a powerful politician.

credit.__text: Angela Ponce for The New York Times

item.title: Ingrid Betancourt to Make a Bid for President of Colombia
description: Ingrid Betancourt’s candidacy comes at a critical time, when Colombians are fed up with the political establishment and the future of the peace agreement is at stake.

description.__text: Ingrid Betancourt, the politician and former FARC hostage, said she would run for president. Her bid comes as the country is at a critical crossroads.

credit.__text: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times

item.title: Why a Stranded Barge Has Become a Popular Vancouver Photo Spot
description: Washed ashore during a fierce November storm, a massive barge has become both a popular sightseeing spot and meme in Vancouver.

description.__text: The beached barge is a favorite spot to take selfies in Vancouver. It crashed ashore during a November storm, initially raising fear that it might collide with the Burrard Bridge, a  historic, four-lane truss bridge in the background.

credit.__text: Martin Tessler for The New York Times

item.title: Tonga Shrouded by Ash and Mystery After Powerful Volcano Erupts
description: So far, the only deaths reported occurred 6,000 miles away, in Peru. But outside emergency workers have yet to make their way to the Pacific island nation.

description.__text: A satellite image showing the undersea volcano eruption, right, off the Pacific nation of Tonga.

creator.__text: Natasha Frost, Mitra Taj and Eric Nagourney

credit.__text: National Institute of Information and Communications Technology (NICT), via Associated Press

item.title: Ontario Town Still Searching for Answers in Gas Leak Explosion
description: Hundreds of people in Wheatley, Ontario, are still out of their homes four months after a gas leak blew up three buildings in the town’s center.

description.__text: The center of Wheatley, Ontario, has been closed off since August.

credit.__text: Tara Walton for The New York Times

item.title: Mass Trials in Cuba Deepen Its Harshest Crackdown in Decades
description: Following nationwide demonstrations last year, more than 60 people were put on trial this week, some facing up to 30 years behind bars.

description.__text: Thousands of Cubans demonstrated in Havana in July.

category.__text: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Journalists in El Salvador Targeted With Spyware Intended for Criminals
description: The announcement came months after the U.S. government blacklisted the Israeli firm that produces Pegasus, the technology used to target the journalists.

description.__text: Spyware has been found on the phones of 22 reporters and editors from the El Faro newspaper in El Salvador over the last year.

category.__text: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Miami-Bound Passenger Storms Cockpit in Honduras, Causing Flight Delay
description: As the American Airlines flight was boarding on Tuesday afternoon, the passenger entered the cockpit and “caused damage,” the airline said.

description.__text: Airlines have had to deal with thousands of cancellations and delays in recent months.

credit.__text: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times

item.title: Citigroup seeks a split from a Mexico business that brought it riches and scandal.
description: The business, known as Banamex, has generated heavy regulatory scrutiny.

description.__text: Citi bought Banco Nacional de México, better known as Banamex, in 2001 for $12.5 billion.

credit.__text: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times

item.title: Source of Mysterious Gas Leak Explosion in Canadian Town Stumps Officials
description: An explosion last summer in an Ontario community built on 19th-century gas wells has left locals searching for answers and some certainty that their town will ever recover.

description.__text: Downtown Wheatley, Ontario, where a large gas explosion last August destroyed three buildings.

credit.__text: Tara Walton for The New York Times

item.title: Haitian Prime Minister Had Close Links With Murder Suspect
description: New evidence suggests the man who took over from Haiti’s murdered president had close links to a prime suspect in the assassination — and that the two stayed in contact even after the crime.

description.__text: President Jovenel Moïse, who was assassinated in July, led Haiti by decree and turned to authoritarian tactics.

category.__text: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

credit.__text: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times

item.title: Cliff Collapses on Boaters in Brazil, Killing 10
description: The tragedy in Minas Gerais state gripped the nation because it was captured on videos that showed an immense slab of rock smashing into pleasure boats.

description.__text: A canyon in Lake Furnas, near Capitólio in southeast Brazil.

item.title: The James Webb Telescope Finishes Deployment in Space
description: Everything is going great for the James Webb Space Telescope. So far.

description.__text: An artist’s concept of the fully deployed and unfolded James Webb Space Telescope, which is currently on its way to a spot called L2, where it will orbit the sun. It is now 600,000 miles from Earth.

item.title: BlackBerry Phone Service Officially Ends
description: BlackBerry was once Canada’s most valuable company and a global force in tech. The final step in its downfall as a phone maker arrived this week.

description.__text: A BlackBerry poster at a trade fair in Hanover, Germany, in 2008.

item.title: Covid Cases Reach Pandemic High at Guantánamo Bay
description: The American base has reinstated a mandate for wearing masks indoors in response to an increase in infections.

description.__text: Members of the American military waiting for their turn to be vaccinated at the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba in September. Infections at the base have reached a pandemic high.

item.title: Airlines Strand Passengers Who Partied on Flight Without Masks
description: A group of Canadian social media influencers and others flouted Covid-19 rules on a flight to Cancún, Mexico, resulting in airlines leaving many of them without a way home.

description.__text: Maskless Canadian passengers partied on a Sunwing Airlines plane. Now they are being investigated for violating the country’s aviation rules and Covid restrictions.

item.title: How Many Bagels Does It Take to Keep a Place in Business?
description: Two quintessential bagel shops dish on the business of selling lots and lots of bagels.

item.title: Dozens Die in Church Stampede in Liberia
description: Worshipers were gathered for a revival meeting in the Liberian capital, when word of armed gang members robbing people set off deadly panic.

description.__text: People search through piles of shoes left in a panicked stampede in Monrovia, Liberia, that left 29 people dead.

item.title: Mining Truck Explodes in Ghana, Killing Dozens
description: The number of dead is not yet known, but the blast flattened buildings in a small town and left a large crater.

creator.__text: Ruth Maclean, Philip Nii Lartey, Elian Peltier and Joseph Quayson

item.title: This ‘Plastic Man’ Has a Cape and a Superhero’s Mission: Cleaning Up Senegal
description: Dressed head to toe in plastic, Modou Fall is a familiar sight in Dakar. But however playful his costume, his goal couldn’t be more serious: ridding the capital of the scourge of plastic bags.

description.__text: Modou Fall, who works to educate fellow Senegalase residents about the dangers of plastic trash, making his case at the annual marathon in Dakar, Senegal, in November.

credit.__text: Ricci Shryock for The New York Times

item.title: Sudan’s Security Forces Kill Protesters as U.S. Diplomats’ Visit Nears
description: Seven people died after being shot at demonstrations in the northeast African country, a doctors’ group said, bringing the civilian death toll since the military seized back power to 71.

description.__text: Protesters took to the streets of Sudan’s capital, Khartoum, on Monday to demand a return to civilian rule.

category.__text: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: The Eerie, Lunar Nothingness of Namibia’s Skeleton Coast
description: The stretch of coastline in southwest Africa is a strange and beautiful reminder that, in the end, we are powerless against nature and time.

description.__text: The C34 highway, along Namibia’s coast, is barely distinguishable from the surrounding desert.

item.title: Ibrahim Boubacar Keita, Malian President Ousted in 2020, Dies at 76
description: Mr. Keita was elected in 2013 with a mandate to stem the country’s many crises. But during his tenure, they escalated.

description.__text: Ibrahim Boubacar Keita at the United Nations in New York in 2019. He came to power after a coup, and was ousted after another.

credit.__text: Dave Sanders for The New York Times

item.title: FIFA's Best? Pitso Mosimane Doesn't Fit the Model
description: Pitso Mosimane enjoyed a better 2021 than almost any coach in world soccer. Just don’t expect FIFA, or soccer, to notice.

description.__text: Pitso Mosimane with the African Super Cup, one of the three continental titles he won with Al Ahly in 2021.

item.title: Pause in Zimbabwe Trial of Freelance Reporter for The Times
description: The trial of Jeffrey Moyo, accused of having fabricated accreditation cards for two New York Times journalists, will resume next month.

description.__text: Jeffrey Moyo leaving the courtroom earlier this week in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe, with his wife, Purity, in pink dress.

item.title: Nigeria Lifts Twitter Ban
description: The social media site had been blocked after it deleted a post from President Muhammadu Buhari about secessionist groups that was widely seen as threatening.

description.__text: President Mohammadu Buhari of Nigeria in December. Some saw his tweet as a threat against the Igbo ethnic group.

credit.__text: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Cameroon's Goalkeeper André Onana Just Wants to Play
description: Cameroon’s 25-year-old goalkeeper has already had his career interrupted twice by bans. Now he’s back, and eager to move on.

description.__text: André Onana, pride of Cameroon’s Indomitable Lions.

item.title: Car Bomb in Mogadishu, Somalia's Capital, Kills 8
description: The explosion, one of a string of recent attacks, comes as the country grapples with a political standoff and a growing humanitarian crisis.

description.__text: The scene of a car bombing in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Wednesday. A news site associated with Al Shabab said the militant group had carried out the attack.

item.title: On Day Biden Calls Ethiopia’s Leader to Urge Peace, a Drone Strike Kills 17
description: The attack came days after over 50 people were killed in a strike on a refugee camp, highlighting the growing role of armed drones in a destructive war.

description.__text: Survivors of an air strike by Ethiopian government forces at a hospital in the town of Dedebit, in the northern region of Tigray, Ethiopia, on Saturday.

item.title: Suspect in South Africa’s Parliament Fire Is Sent for Psychiatric Check
description: If the man is found fit to stand trial, he will face charges that now include terrorism. His lawyers said he would protest with a hunger strike.

description.__text: Zandile Christmas Mafe, who is suspected of setting the fire that tore through South Africa’s Parliament buildings, appeared in court in Cape Town on Tuesday.

item.title: In South Africa, Success Against H.I.V. Offers Hope
description: A former Africa correspondent, who covered the height of the AIDS epidemic there 15 years ago, finds lessons in the remarkable progress against that virus for our current fight.

description.__text: A near-empty ward of the Chongwe District Hospital outside Lusaka, Zambia. Fifteen years ago, a hospital like this would have been overflowing with H.I.V. patients lying two or three to a bed.

item.title: Freelance Reporter for the New York Times Is On Trial in Zimbabwe
description: The reporter, Jeffrey Moyo, has been accused of helping two Times journalists enter Zimbabwe from South Africa using bogus credentials, a charge that even the government admits is on ‘shaky ground.’

description.__text: Jeffrey Moyo, second from left, conferring with his lawyers, Doug Coltart and Beatrice Mtetwa, outside the courtroom in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe, on Tuesday, as Mr. Moyo’s wife, Purity, second from right, listens. Mr. Moyo’s trial begins on Wednesday.

item.title: Uganda Reopens Schools After World’s Longest Covid Shutdown
description: Many countries have closed classrooms on and off, but Uganda had kept more than 10 million students at home since March 2020. Critics say it took a heavy toll.

description.__text: Children back in class at Kitante Primary School in Kampala, Uganda, on Monday.

creator.__text: Musinguzi Blanshe and Abdi Latif Dahir

credit.__text: Esther Ruth Mbabazi for The New York Times

item.title: Jawar Mohammed to Be Released From Prison by Ethiopian President
description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed declared the amnesty on Orthodox Christmas and offered to start a dialogue with some opponents after 14 months of war.

description.__text: Oromos calling for the release of prominent opposition figures in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, in October.

category.__text: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: In ‘African Origin’ Show at Met, New Points of Light Across Cultures
description: Holdings from Ancient Egypt and sub-Saharan Africa come together in a masterpiece show. Now the Met should make clear how the wondrous works got here.

description.__text: Partnerships: Spanning eras and cultures, a pairing of artworks from “The African Origin of Civilization” includes “The King’s Acquaintances Memi and Sabu” from Egypt, ca. 2575–2465 B.C. and “Seated Couple” from Mali, 18th or early 19th century.

credit.__text: Seth Caplan for The New York Times

item.title: Mystery Deepens as Suspect Is Charged in South Africa Parliament Fire
description: The man was also accused of possessing explosives, stealing laptops and breaking security laws. Former neighbors were shocked. His lawyer said the government was rushing to find a scapegoat.

description.__text: Zandile Christmas Mafe was charged with arson, theft and housebreaking in connection with the fire.

item.title: Sudan Braces for ‘the Worst’ after Prime Minister Resigns
description: With the departure of the civilian prime minister Abdalla Hamdok on Sunday, the military and security forces are now fully in control of Sudan again.

description.__text: People chant slogans during a protest to denounce the October 2021 military coup, in Khartoum on Sunday.

category.__text: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Tougher Words on Russia
description: The West stressed a unified response after Biden’s stumble.

description.__text: The Ukrainian military on the front line of Katerynivka, in the Luhansk Oblast province of eastern Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Drops Its Case Against M.I.T. Scientist Accused of Hiding China Links
description: Gang Chen, a professor of mechanical engineering, was arrested a year ago, accused of concealing his affiliations with Chinese government institutions.

description.__text: Gang Chen, an M.I.T. scientist, was arrested in 2021 as part of the China Initiative, a government anti-espionage effort that has come under criticism for singling out scientists of Chinese heritage.

item.title: Zara Rutherford Becomes Youngest Woman to Circle the Globe Solo
description: When Zara Rutherford landed on Thursday, she became the youngest woman to circumnavigate the globe solo. “I’m just happy to finally also be in the same spot for a few months,” she said.

description.__text: Zara Rutherford greets supporters after landing at an airport in Kortrijk, Belgium, on Thursday.

item.title: Lockdown Made Their Second Date Last Weeks. Would Romance Bloom?
description: Sparks didn’t fly on their first blind date. Then the city shut down while she was visiting.

item.title: This Ancient Brew Has Retro Appeal in South Korea
description: Makgeolli, a rice wine made by Korean farmers for centuries, has become a cosmopolitan sensation over the past decade. The buzz grew during Covid lockdowns.

description.__text: Han A-young, the owner of Hanayangjo, labelling bottles of makgeolli she made in Seoul, in June.

creator.__text: Chang W. Lee and Mike Ives

credit.__text: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: The Plans for the World’s Next Largest City Are Incomplete
description: Delhi is growing far beyond the formal confines of the city, a case study in the complexity of what we call urbanization.

item.title: Ash From Tonga Volcanic Eruption Still Poses a Threat
description: Ash from a volcanic eruption in the South Pacific nation presents risks to drinking water and air quality, experts say. Quantifying them in real time is a challenge.

description.__text: Heavy ash fell over Nomuka, Tonga, as seen from a New Zealand military surveillance flight on Monday.

credit.__text: New Zealand Defence Force, via Reuters

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Blinken Visits Ukraine
description: U.S. officials pushed back on Moscow’s negotiation demands.

description.__text: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, right, met Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, in Kyiv on Wednesday.

item.title: Drone Strike Video Shows Killing of Civilians in Afghanistan
description: The New York Times obtained footage of the botched strike in Kabul, whose victims included seven children, through a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit.

creator.__text: Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt, Azmat Khan, Evan Hill and Christoph Koettl

category.__text: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Belgium Convicts 18 in People-Smuggling Case Tied to U.K. Truck Deaths
description: A Belgian court convicted a man said to have been the leader of a human trafficking operation that resulted in the deaths of 39 Vietnamese migrants in 2019. More than a dozen others were also found guilty.

description.__text: The bodies were discovered in a truck parked at Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays, east of London, more than two years ago.

item.title: Japan places Tokyo and 12 other prefectures under a quasi-state of emergency because of Omicron.

description.__text: Tokyo last week. Thirteen additional prefectures in Japan will be placed under a quasi-state of emergency because of a rise in Omicron cases.

item.title: China's Rising Menace Hardens Taiwan's Separate Identity
description: More than ever, Taiwan defines itself by its democratic values. Beijing’s military and diplomatic threats only reinforce the island’s separateness.

description.__text: Li Yuan-hsin, right, with her husband and daughter at a day care center in Chiayi, Taiwan. Ms. Li is among the more than 60 percent of the island’s people who identify as solely Taiwanese.

creator.__text: Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien

credit.__text: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A Race to Dominate the Metaverse
description: Microsoft said it planned to buy the video game company Activision Blizzard for nearly $70 billion.

description.__text: Playing Call of Duty: Black Ops at Paris Games Week in 2018.

item.title: N.B.A.’s Warriors Disavow Part-Owner’s Uyghur Comments
description: The Golden State Warriors distanced themselves from a minority stakeholder, Chamath Palihapitiya, who said “nobody cares” about the Uyghurs, the ethnic group that has faced a deadly crackdown in China.

description.__text: Chamath Palihapitiya, who runs a venture capital firm, said on his podcast that concern about human rights abuses outside the United States was “a luxury belief.”

category.__text: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Hong Kong Will Cull Thousands of Hamsters After Covid Cases
description: Officials said it was not clear that the virus had been transmitted to humans from the animals. But they called on residents to surrender recently imported hamsters.

description.__text: Two people and at least 11 hamsters connected to the Little Boss pet shop in Hong Kong tested positive for Covid.

item.title: Two Earthquakes in Afghanistan Kill at Least 27
description: The quakes struck about two hours apart in a western border province along the border with Turkmenistan.

description.__text: Afghan villagers removing bricks after their home was damaged by Monday’s earthquake in the remote western province of Badghis.

item.title: After Tonga's Volcano Eruption, Worries Grow About Covid Exposure
description: Aid workers risk bringing in a virus Tonga has so far kept out. But there are more immediate problems, as its government confirmed in its first statement since the disaster.

description.__text: Vista de una densa caída de ceniza en Nomuka, Tonga, el lunes

creator.__text: Damien Cave, Isabella Kwai and Eric Nagourney

credit.__text: Fuerza de Defensa de Nueva Zelanda

item.title: 2 Earthquakes in Remote Area of Western Afghanistan Kill at Least 22
description: There were fears the death toll could rise as the first rescuers reached some of the mountainous villages struck by the temblors in one of Afghanistan’s most impoverished regions.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China Limits Olympic Spectators
description: Tickets for the Winter Olympics will not be sold to the public.

description.__text: Installations for the 2022 Winter Olympic Games and Paralympic Games in Beijing.

item.title: China Won't Sell Olympics Tickets to Chinese Public

description.__text: Workers preparing the ice last week in the Beijing Capitol Indoor Stadium ahead of the Winter Games.

item.title: France Sets Timeline to Lift Covid Restrictions in February
description: The prime minister announced that the easing of restrictions in February would be done in stages.

description.__text: French teachers and school employees protested in Paris on Thursday against the government's handling of the Covid-19 crisis in schools.

credit.__text: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: 80 Years Ago the Nazis Planned the ‘Final Solution.’ It Took 90 Minutes.
description: As Germany observes the anniversary of the Wannsee Conference, witnesses of the Nazi era are dying and antisemitism is resurgent in Europe and the United States.

description.__text: Portraits of European Jews murdered during the Holocaust, at the Holocaust Memorial in Berlin, on Wednesday.

item.title: Hardy Kruger, German-Born Hollywood Star, Is Dead at 93
description: Escaping execution by the Nazis for “cowardice” as a soldier, he found success in films because he found ways to portray “the new, good German.”

description.__text: The German actor Hardy Kruger and Nicole Courcel in the Oscar-winning French film “Sundays and Cybèle” (1962).

item.title: ‘She Was Just Going for a Run’: Anger in Ireland Over Teacher’s Murder
description: Ashling Murphy, a 23-year-old first-grade teacher, was out jogging when she was attacked. Her death has prompted outrage over women’s safety.

description.__text: Students of Ashling Murphy held portraits of her at her funeral in Mountbolus, Ireland, on Wednesday.

item.title: How, and Why, Boris Johnson Could Lose His Job as U.K. Prime Minister
description: Mr. Johnson’s future is in doubt after two humiliating apologies about parties while the country was under Covid restrictions. Here’s a guide to how he could be forced out, or fight on.

description.__text: Escaping scrapes is one of Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s career-defining political skills.

item.title: On Ukraine and Russia, Biden Flusters European Allies by Stating the Obvious
description: After the president laid bare divisions over Russian meddling in Ukraine, his administration scrambled to get on the same page with European allies.

description.__text: A Ukrainian soldier on the front line in Zolote, eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Benedict Faulted for Handling of Abuse Cases When He Was an Archbishop
description: A newly released report by a law firm said the former pope mishandled at least four cases of sexual abuse accusations in Germany.

description.__text: Pope Benedict in the Vatican in 2013, days before his resignation took effect.

creator.__text: Jason Horowitz, Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani

item.title: Zara Rutherford Becomes Youngest Woman to Circle the Globe Solo
description: When Zara Rutherford landed on Thursday, she became the youngest woman to circumnavigate the globe solo. “I’m just happy to finally also be in the same spot for a few months,” she said.

description.__text: Zara Rutherford greets supporters after landing at an airport in Kortrijk, Belgium, on Thursday.

item.title: 1922: Thief Returns Diplomat’s Stolen Wallet
description: After the official issued a personal plea to the person he suspected of being the culprit, his wallet was returned, with some cash missing but other possessions intact.

item.title: American Airlines Flight Turns Back Over Passenger Mask Dispute
description: The London-bound flight was about 500 miles into its 4,400-mile journey when it reversed course and returned to Miami.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Will Putin act on Ukraine?

description.__text: A Ukrainian soldier this week on the front line of Katerynivka, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Biden Predicts Russia Will Invade Ukraine
description: President Biden’s comments went well beyond the formal intelligence assessments described by White House officials, which conclude that Russia’s president has not yet decided whether to invade.

description.__text: President Biden’s comments went well beyond the current intelligence assessments described by White House officials.

item.title: Russia and Iran Put on a Show of Unity — Against the U.S.
description: Vladimir V. Putin met at the Kremlin with Iran’s new leader, Ebrahim Raisi, at a time when both their countries, despite their differences, are at odds with Washington.

creator.__text: Anton Troianovski, Farnaz Fassihi and Steven Erlanger

item.title: Ricardo Bofill, Architect of Otherworldly Buildings, Dies at 82
description: His structures were so bold, they were the backdrops for TV shows and films, including “Westworld” and a “Hunger Games” movie. But they were also socially aware.

item.title: Syrian Doctor Accused of Atrocities Goes on Trial in Germany
description: The charges against Alaa Mousa include torturing opponents of the Assad regime in military hospitals in Syria, and murdering at least one by lethal injection.

description.__text: A Syrian doctor, Alaa Mousa, went on trial in Frankfurt, Germany, on Wednesday, charged with torturing opponents of the Syrian regime and murdering one of them.

category.__text: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Gaspard Ulliel, 37, 'Moon Knight' and 'Hannibal Rising' Star, Dies Skiing
description: He gained fame as a young Hannibal Lecter and the designer Yves Saint Laurent. He died after a skiing accident weeks before he is to appear in a Disney+ series.

description.__text: Gaspard Ulliel in 2019. “His sensitivity and the intensity of his acting” made him “an exceptional actor,” the French culture minister said.

item.title: A Trove of Old Photos Could Reveal the Future of These Arctic Glaciers
description: The Svalbard Islands, part of Norway, are warming seven times faster than the global average. Aerial pictures from the 1930s are helping researchers understand what that means for the region’s ice.

item.title: Court in Ukraine Declines Request to Arrest Former President
description: A feud between President Volodymyr Zelensky and his predecessor, Petro O. Poroshenko, has carried on despite the risk the country is facing from Russia.

item.title: Undeterred by Omicron, Tourists Seek Sun in a Welcoming Spain
description: For decades, Spain has been a prime destination for European snowbirds. Even as the Omicron variant spreads, the country is keeping its doors wide open to visitors.

description.__text: Tourists watching the sunset from a vantage point on Lanzarote, one of the Canary Islands.

credit.__text: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times

item.title: Silvio Berlusconi Angles for Italy’s Presidency, Bunga Bunga and All
description: The billionaire former prime minister is working hard to persuade lawmakers to vote for him next week, despite an unusual résumé for a job resting on moral authority.

description.__text: Silvio Berlusconi in Milan in October.

item.title: The U.S. Bombed a Dam in Syria That Was on a ‘No-Strike’ List
description: A military report warned that striking the giant structure could cause tens of thousands of deaths.

description.__text: A worker at the Tabqa Dam in 2017.

creator.__text: Dave Philipps, Azmat Khan and Eric Schmitt

category.__text: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Palestinian American Died Handcuffed in Israeli Custody, Witnesses Say
description: Omar Assad, 78, had hoped to see his children in the U.S. one more time. Instead he died after being detained by Israeli soldiers.

description.__text: The funeral for Omar Assad, 78, who died after he was detained by Israeli soldiers, in Jiljilya last week.

item.title: Kamal Mouzawak Is Championing Lebanon's Culinary Traditions
description: At home and now in Paris, Kamal Mouzawak empowers Lebanese communities through food. Not even the horrific port blast in 2020 has stopped him.

item.title: Russia and Iran Put on a Show of Unity — Against the U.S.
description: Vladimir V. Putin met at the Kremlin with Iran’s new leader, Ebrahim Raisi, at a time when both their countries, despite their differences, are at odds with Washington.

creator.__text: Anton Troianovski, Farnaz Fassihi and Steven Erlanger

item.title: Syrian Doctor Accused of Atrocities Goes on Trial in Germany
description: The charges against Alaa Mousa include torturing opponents of the Assad regime in military hospitals in Syria, and murdering at least one by lethal injection.

description.__text: A Syrian doctor, Alaa Mousa, went on trial in Frankfurt, Germany, on Wednesday, charged with torturing opponents of the Syrian regime and murdering one of them.

category.__text: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Israel Evicts Palestinians in Sheikh Jarrah Area of Jerusalem
description: Israelis evicted an extended family and destroyed their homes in the Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood, where attempted evictions last year helped spark a war with Gaza.

creator.__text: Patrick Kingsley and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad

item.title: A fourth shot may not offer much more protection against catching Omicron, an early Israeli study suggests.
description: The small study adds information to the debate over whether a fourth shot is advisable.

description.__text: A resident receives a fourth dose of the coronavirus vaccine at a nursing home in Tel Mond, Israel, earlier this month.

item.title: Yemen’s Houthi Militia Claims Rare Military Strike on U.A.E.
description: Emirati officials said that several people had been killed in an explosion of fuel tankers in Abu Dhabi, apparently caused by a drone attack.

description.__text: An Abu Dhabi National Oil Company storage facility on Monday.

creator.__text: Shuaib Almosawa, Vivian Yee and Isabella Kwai

item.title: Israeli Artist Turns Plastic Pollution Into ‘Earth Poetica’
description: In Beverly Barkat’s quest to connect people with nature, she found that environmental waste could be a powerful medium.

description.__text: Beverly Barkat in her Jerusalem studio assembling “Earth Poetica,” a huge globe, from plastic waste. Its permanent home will be a building at ground zero in Manhattan.

credit.__text: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times

item.title: A Ban on 19 Singers in Egypt Tests the Old Guard’s Power
description: Leaders of a musicians’ licensing group are trying to curb mahraganat, a bold genre wildly popular with young people. It is not clear if they can.

description.__text: Mahraganat music played at a bachelor party in 2019 in Cairo, where the genre is very popular.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Lawyers Discuss a Plea Bargain to End His Graft Trial
description: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s former prime minister, has pleaded not guilty in a corruption case. But his lawyers are negotiating a deal in which he might accept some charges to avoid jail time.

description.__text: Benjamin Netanyahu at a hearing in Jerusalem in November. The talks are the latest twist in a legal process that began in 2016 after claims that Mr. Netanyahu had accepted gifts in exchange for political favors.

item.title: 32 Years After Civil War, Mundane Moments Trigger Awful Memories
description: Cards. Candles. Sunsets. For this New York Times correspondent and other children of Beirut in the 1980s, traumatic reminders of the war are still there in everyday activities.

description.__text: Everyday items like candles can trigger traumatic memories of the war. As sweeping power outages in Beirut continue, residents have once again found themselves living by candlelight.

category.__text: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Oil Prices Stay High as Output From OPEC and Others Falls Behind
description: OPEC Plus, the United States and others have been slow to ramp up output, lagging production goals.

description.__text: An oil refinery in Port Arthur, Texas. Lagging production of oil worldwide has been sending prices to seven-year highs and driving inflation.

category.__text: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

credit.__text: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

item.title: Majid Al Futtaim, Who Helped Build Modern Dubai, Dies at 87
description: His real estate empire, including malls, grocery stores and luxury hotels, transformed the Persian Gulf city into a global tourism hub.

description.__text: The Mall of Emirates in Dubai. Majid Al Futtaim, who opened the mall at the height of the Persian Gulf region’s economic boom, brought the Western-style consumer experience to the gulf.

item.title: Rockets Possibly Fired by Pro-Iran Assailants Target U.S. Embassy in Iraq
description: Four rockets were fired at the fortified compound that houses the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, and suspicion fell on pro-Iran militias.

description.__text: A militia protest outside the U.S. embassy in Baghdad last month.

category.__text: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: First Trial for Syrian State Atrocities Yields Guilty Verdict in Germany
description: A German court found a former Syrian intelligence officer guilty of crimes against humanity and sentenced him to life in prison — a first after a decade of war.

description.__text: The former Syrian intelligence officer Anwar Raslan in the courtroom on Thursday in Koblenz, Germany.

category.__text: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Palestinian American Dies of Heart Attack After Brief Detention by Israeli Troops
description: The elderly man, who was identified as Omar Asad, had been held during a raid by the Israeli Army on a Palestinian village in the occupied West Bank.

description.__text: A poster of Omar Asad, who died shortly after being detained by Israeli troops, in the West Bank village of Jiljilya on Wednesday.

item.title: The U.S. and Iran Move Closer to a Nuclear Deal
description: As negotiations reach a critical stage, neither side wants to betray weakness by seeming too eager to reach a deal.

description.__text: Iranian officials standing near missiles put on display by the Revolutionary Guard in Tehran on Friday. Despite their bombastic talk, Iranian officials seem optimistic about reaching a nuclear deal with the U.S.

category.__text: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Aras Amiri Has Returned to the U.K. After Being Jailed in Iran
description: Aras Amiri, an arts worker employed by the British Council, was arrested in March 2018 on espionage charges. She was acquitted in August and flew back to Britain earlier this week.

description.__text: Aras Amiri was employed by the British Council for five years in London prior to being arrested in Iran.

item.title: Saudi Princess Is Released, but Other Royals Are Still Locked Up
description: The Saudi government has not said why it detained or freed Princess Basmah bint Saud, a daughter of a former king who has criticized the country’s policies.

description.__text: Princess Basmah bint Saud in Washington in 2017 during a discussion about the role of women in the Middle East.

category.__text: Basmah bint Saud, Princess of Saudi Arabia

item.title: Why Whales Don’t Choke
description: Scientists have discovered a new anatomical structure that allows lunge-feeding whales to take in massive amounts of water without choking.

description.__text: A humpback whale lunge feeding off Vancouver Island in Canada.

item.title: U.S. Drops Its Case Against M.I.T. Scientist Accused of Hiding China Links
description: Gang Chen, a professor of mechanical engineering, was arrested a year ago, accused of concealing his affiliations with Chinese government institutions.

description.__text: Gang Chen, an M.I.T. scientist, was arrested in 2021 as part of the China Initiative, a government anti-espionage effort that has come under criticism for singling out scientists of Chinese heritage.

item.title: A New Map of the Sun’s Local Bubble
description: At the edge of a vast region devoid of gas and dust, scientists find an explanation for “how all nearby star formation began.”

item.title: Sprawling Coral Reef Resembling Roses Is Discovered Off Tahiti
description: The reef, which is just under two miles long and is in “pristine” condition, was found by a team of divers mapping the ocean floor for UNESCO.

description.__text: A coral reef resembling a bed of roses was discovered off the coast of Tahiti.

category.__text: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: ‘Major Discovery’ Beneath Antarctic Seas: A Giant Icefish Breeding Colony
description: Scientists discovered a mammoth nesting ground with an estimated 60 million icefish nests in the Weddell Sea.

item.title: Sometimes, Life Stinks. So He Invented the Nasal Ranger.
description: For Chuck McGinley, an engineer who devised the go-to instrument for measuring odors, helping people understand what they smell is serious science.

description.__text: Chuck McGinley with his Nasal Ranger, a design inspired by the shape of the Haleakala volcano in Hawaii.

credit.__text: Caroline Yang for The New York Times

item.title: Checking Privilege in the Animal Kingdom
description: Researchers say the human concepts of intergenerational wealth and inequality are useful for studying some animals’ behavior.

description.__text: Check your privilege, squirrel.

item.title: How European Royals Once Shared Their Most Important Secrets
description: Recent research highlights the use of letterlocking techniques by Queen Elizabeth, Catherine de’ Medici and Mary Queen of Scots.

description.__text: A letter from Mary Queen of Scots, sent on Feb. 8, 1587, to Henry III, king of France. The letter was written and locked just hours before Mary was executed for treason.

category.__text: Elizabeth I, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Deborah Nickerson, Pioneering Genome Researcher, Dies at 67
description: Using the Human Genome Project as her guide, she helped find genes responsible for cardiovascular disease, autism and a rare disorder called Miller syndrome.

item.title: Kidneys From a Genetically Altered Pig Are Implanted in a Brain-Dead Patient
description: Surgeons at the University of Alabama at Birmingham said they hoped to start clinical trials with kidney patients later this year.

item.title: Predictions Favored Solar Over Wind Power. What Happened?
description: One lesson: Renewable technology benefits from early, consistent government support.

item.title: ‘Build Back Better’ Hit a Wall, but Climate Action Could Move Forward
description: Some Democrats want to forge ahead with a stand-alone climate bill, but their solution could mean abandoning other parts of President Biden’s agenda.

description.__text: “I think it’s clear that we would be able to get support for the $500 billion plus for energy and the environment,” President Biden said of Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: Most ‘Havana Syndrome’ Cases Unlikely Caused by Foreign Power, C.I.A. Says
description: A report concluded that most cases have environmental or medical causes, but the government remains focused on investigating two dozen incidents that remain unexplained.

description.__text: About 1,000 cases of the mysterious illness that initially appeared at the U.S. Embassy in Havana have been reported, but of those, the C.I.A. is now focusing on about two dozen unexplained incidents.

item.title: Why Are Men More Likely to Die of Covid? It’s Complicated.
description: Sex differences in Covid death rates vary widely from state to state, suggesting they are rooted in behavior as well as biology.

description.__text: A Covid-19 patient in the intensive care unit of a hospital in La Mesa, Calif.

item.title: Sara McLanahan, Who Studied Single Motherhood, Dies at 81
description: A Princeton sociologist and a single mother herself, she brought her own experience to her wide body of scholarly work.

item.title: In Sewage, Clues to Omicron’s Surge
description: Tracking the virus in wastewater is helping some cities and hospitals respond to the most recent wave of the coronavirus, but a more coordinated national effort is needed, experts say.

description.__text: Workers in Monaco took sewage water samples to detect coronavirus concentration in the area in 2021.

item.title: How Anxiety Can Benefit Us
description: There are several benefits to having an internal alarm system, experts say.

item.title: New Research Shows How Health Risks to Children Mount as Temperatures Rise
description: The first nationwide study on rising temperatures and younger Americans found that hotter days were associated with more visits to emergency rooms.

description.__text: A misting station in Queens in August. National research shows that children face particular dangers during heat waves.

item.title: Searching for Pfizer’s Paxlovid Pills When Mom Got Covid
description: The experience showed how hard it is for many people to get potentially lifesaving treatments.

description.__text: Mary Ann Neilsen, the author’s mother, holding her last Paxlovid pills while recovering from Covid-19.

credit.__text: Alex Welsh for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Administration Announces Plan to Spend Billions to Prevent Wildfires
description: The plan is an expensive one, but it is only partially funded.

credit.__text: Max Whittaker for The New York Times

item.title: Here’s What Scientists Know About the Tonga Volcano Eruption
description: The explosion probably won’t cool the planet as some previous eruptions have done, but it could affect weather in the short term.

description.__text: The Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha’apai volcano, off the coast of Tonga, on Friday.

item.title: After Tonga's Volcano Eruption, Worries Grow About Covid Exposure
description: Aid workers risk bringing in a virus Tonga has so far kept out. But there are more immediate problems, as its government confirmed in its first statement since the disaster.

description.__text: Vista de una densa caída de ceniza en Nomuka, Tonga, el lunes

creator.__text: Damien Cave, Isabella Kwai and Eric Nagourney

credit.__text: Fuerza de Defensa de Nueva Zelanda

item.title: In Arkansas, Trans Teens Await an Uncertain Future
description: Even as the medical community grapples with how best to provide care to transgender adolescents, some states seek to ban it outright.

credit.__text: Liz Sanders for The New York Times

item.title: A California City Is Overrun by Crows. Could a Laser Be the Answer?
description: In a move befitting its Silicon Valley setting, the city of Sunnyvale, Calif., will aim a laser at 1,000 birds that have overwhelmed the downtown area during the pandemic.

description.__text: Crows fly near downtown Sunnyvale, Calif.

category.__text: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

item.title: The Eerie, Lunar Nothingness of Namibia’s Skeleton Coast
description: The stretch of coastline in southwest Africa is a strange and beautiful reminder that, in the end, we are powerless against nature and time.

description.__text: The C34 highway, along Namibia’s coast, is barely distinguishable from the surrounding desert.

item.title: The C.D.C.’s New Challenge? Grappling With Imperfect Science
description: The Omicron coronavirus variant is moving much faster than researchers can, worsening a longstanding problem: The agency must make tough decisions with scant data.

description.__text: Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the C.D.C. director, right, and Dr. Anthony Fauci of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, during a Senate hearing in November.

category.__text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

credit.__text: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times

item.title: How The mRNA Vaccines Were Made: Halting Progress and Happy Accidents
description: The stunning Covid vaccines manufactured by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna drew upon long-buried discoveries made in the hopes of ending past epidemics.

description.__text: A 3-D plaster model of a coronavirus spike protein in the office of Dr. Barney Graham of the Vaccine Research Center of the National Institutes of Health.

credit.__text: Johnathon Kelso for The New York Times

item.title: Howard Solomon, 94, Dies; His Business Success Had a Personal Connection
description: After one of his sons fell into a deep depression, he helped him recover. He later licensed an antidepressant that was a boon to his pharmaceutical company.

item.title: The Kunga Was a Status Symbol Long Before the Thoroughbred
description: A new study finds the first known instance of a human-engineered hybrid, bred from a donkey and a Syrian wild ass 4,500 years ago.

item.title: For Coronavirus Testing, the Nose May Not Always Be Best
description: As Omicron spreads, some experts are calling for a switch to saliva-based tests, which may detect infections days earlier than nasal swabs do.

description.__text: A saliva Covid-19 testing site at the University of Minnesota Field House in Minneapolis.

credit.__text: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times

item.title: More Young Kids Are Getting Sick From Cannabis Edibles
description: As states legalize cannabis, a growing number of children are inadvertently consuming marijuana-infused foods.

description.__text: To protect children from accidentally ingesting marijuana edibles, some states have passed laws governing how these foods can be packaged and presented.

category.__text: American Assn of Poison Control Centers

credit.__text: Chona Kasinger for The New York Times

item.title: The James Webb Telescope Finishes Deployment in Space
description: Everything is going great for the James Webb Space Telescope. So far.

description.__text: An artist’s concept of the fully deployed and unfolded James Webb Space Telescope, which is currently on its way to a spot called L2, where it will orbit the sun. It is now 600,000 miles from Earth.

item.title: Chinese Rover Finds Moon Cube Is Just Rabbit-Like Rock
description: A blurry image that China’s space program had called the “mystery hut” was a result of camera angle, light and shadow.

item.title: Jim Green, NASA’s Retiring Top Scientist, Says We Can Terraform Mars
description: Jim Green has shaped much of the space agency’s scientific inquiry for decades.

description.__text: James Green, the chief scientist at NASA, has worked for NASA since 1980, overseeing missions across the solar system and contributing to more than 100 scientific papers.

credit.__text: Emily Kask for The New York Times

description: In a lab with lasers, scientists worked out a multi-chromatic mystery observed around the solar system.

description: Here’s a look at what may be launching in the year to come.

item.title: What's Launching to the Moon in 2022
description: Debut rocket launches and robotic lunar missions will make the New Year a crucial prelude to putting astronauts back on the moon.

item.title: Meteor Showers That Will Peak in Night Skies in 2022
description: Find a dark place. Lie back, look up and see what the cosmos has to offer.

item.title: You Don’t Need a Spaceship to Grow ‘Weird Little’ Martian Radishes
description: Scientists on this planet have worked out a variety of techniques to simulate the conditions of other worlds that are near and very far.

description.__text: A mock space suit donned by a participant of a Mars simulation project in Jinchang, China, in 2019.

item.title: NASA-Russia Alliance Is Shaken by Events on Planet Earth
description: The relationship between the nations’ space agencies is facing a series of difficult tests, including an antisatellite weapon and friction over Ukraine.

item.title: Former Interns Say SpaceX Ignored Sexual Harassment
description: Some women at the company, founded by Elon Musk, described feelings of powerlessness and a failure by the company’s human resources office to discipline male employees.

description.__text: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket blasting off from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California in 2019.

item.title: What a Times Journalist Learned From His ‘Don’t Look Up’ Moment
description: A new film about a killer comet revives memories of a nail-biting night in The Times newsroom two decades ago.

description.__text: Jennifer Lawrence and Leonardo DiCaprio are astronomers trying to sound the alarm for a comet heading toward Earth in the film “Don’t Look Up.”

item.title: NASA's DART Mission Launches to Crash Into Killer Asteroid and Defend Earth
description: The Double Asteroid Redirection Test spacecraft, launched on Wednesday, could be the first to alter an asteroid’s path, a technique that may be used to defend the planet in the future.

item.title: A New Map of the Sun’s Local Bubble
description: At the edge of a vast region devoid of gas and dust, scientists find an explanation for “how all nearby star formation began.”

item.title: What We Know About Unfolding the James Webb Space Telescope
description: Engineers sent commands to deploy the mirrors on the space observatory, then latch them into place, a critical milestone before it begins its science mission.

description.__text: An illustration of four stages of the unfolding process of the space telescope, with the fully unfolded telescope at the bottom right.

item.title: A Divided World United to Launch the James Webb Space Telescope
description: “I’ve always seen space as an area where we cooperate, through all the trying times,” said a professor who oversaw mission control for the global effort to launch a $10 billion telescope into space.

description.__text: The mirror of the James Webb Space Telescope in 2016. Its launch on Christmas was a reminder that international cooperation on grand-scale projects was still possible.

item.title: James Webb Space Telescope Launches on Journey to See the Dawn of Starlight
description: Astronomers were jubilant as the spacecraft made it off the launchpad following decades of delays and cost overruns. The Webb is set to offer a new keyhole into the earliest moments of our universe.

description.__text: The James Webb Space Telescope launching into space aboard an Ariane 5 rocket on Christmas morning from the Guiana Space Center in French Guiana.

item.title: How to Watch the James Webb Space Telescope Launch
description: Astronomers have been waiting eagerly for the beginning of the powerful space observatory’s mission, and on Christmas morning they may finally get their wish.

description.__text: An Ariane 5 rocket carrying NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope to the launchpad at the European spaceport in Kourou, French Guiana, on Thursday.

item.title: How NASA's Webb Telescope Overcame Loose Screws, Budgets and Clamps
description: Getting the James Webb Space Telescope to the launchpad has been a difficult journey that has taken decades.

description.__text: Assembly of the James Webb Space Telescope in a Northrop Grumman facility in Redondo Beach, Calif., in 2019.

item.title: Webb Telescope Prepares to Ascend, With an Eye Toward Our Origins
description: The biggest space telescope in history aims to answer astronomy’s oldest question: How did we get from the Big Bang to here?

description.__text: The James Webb Space Telescope, with its five-layer sunshield, deployed in a facility at Northrop Grumman in Redondo Beach, Calif., last year.

item.title: NASA Mission Could Blast an Asteroid That Once Menaced Earth
description: The OSIRIS-REX spacecraft, which collected samples from the asteroid Bennu, would visit a second space rock, Apophis.

description.__text: An artist’s rendering of the OSIRIS-REX spacecraft descending toward the asteroid Bennu to collect a surface sample.

item.title: Exxon Sets a 2050 Goal for Net-Zero Greenhouse Gas Emissions
description: The target does not account for the climate impact of its customers and suppliers, leaving the company lagging the commitments of some of its rivals.

description.__text: An Exxon complex in Baytown, Texas. The company identified 150 modifications that it can make in its operations to help meet its emission goals, it said.

credit.__text: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times

item.title: Mexico Is Buying a Texas Oil Refinery in a Quest for Energy Independence
description: President López Obrador wants to halt most oil exports and imports of gasoline and other fuels. Critics say he is reneging on Mexico’s climate change commitments.

description.__text: The Deer Park refinery, which sits on the Houston ship channel, would be the only major Pemex operation outside Mexico.

credit.__text: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

item.title: Storm Moves Into the Northeast After Heavy Snow in the South
description: The system spawned tornadoes in Florida and knocked out power to nearly 200,000 customers in the Southeast. It could bring a foot or more of snow to western Pennsylvania and northern New York State.

description.__text: Clearing snow in Morganton, N.C. Sunday.

item.title: As Infrastructure Money Flows, Wastewater Improvements Are Key
description: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?

item.title: We Mapped a Year of Extreme Weather
description: The Times analyzed temperature data from weather stations across the United States. The result: 2021 was a huge year for records, both high and low.

item.title: Don’t Just Watch: Team Behind ‘Don’t Look Up’ Urges Climate Action
description: The satirical film about a comet hurtling toward Earth is a metaphor for climate change. It has broken a Netflix record and its director hopes it will mobilize public action.

item.title: Is Norway the Future of Cars?
description: The speed by which electric vehicles have taken over Norway has stunned even the cars’ enthusiasts.

item.title: 2021 Was Earth’s Fifth-Hottest Year, Scientists Say
description: The finding, by European researchers, fits a clear warming trend: The seven hottest years on record have been the past seven.

description.__text: Wildfires near Lytton, British Columbia, in July. The temperature in the town hit 121 degrees Fahrenheit in June, a Canadian record.

item.title: The World Has Changed. So Has ‘52 Places.’
description: Our annual list of destinations to visit this year looks at spots where visitors can be part of the solution to problems like overtourism and climate change.

item.title: U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions Bounced Back Sharply in 2021
description: Emissions rose 6 percent last year after a record 10 percent decline in 2020, fueled by a rise in coal power and truck traffic as the U.S. economy rebounded from the pandemic.

description.__text: Traffic on the Williamsburg Bridge in Manhattan last year. Transportation emissions, the nation’s largest source of greenhouse gases, rose 10 percent in 2021.

credit.__text: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times

description: A relationship is a shared story, even if it’s hard to agree on the details.

item.title: Will Congress Pass New Regulation on Big Tech? Time May Be Running Out.
description: With midterm elections approaching, a vote taken on Thursday could be the first of several that Congress takes on bills aimed at the industry.

description.__text: Senator Charles E. Grassley, along with Senator Amy Klobuchar, has introduced a bill that would bar major tech platforms from giving their own products favorable sales treatment.

item.title: What to Wear in the Metaverse
description: Dressing for a virtual world is going to be both enormously liberating and potentially very, very messy.

item.title: Why Microsoft Wants Activision
description: Activision has a lot of popular games that fit into Microsoft’s plans to build a vast library of titles that can be played on all sorts of devices. The metaverse can wait.

description.__text: When Microsoft announced its plans to buy Activision, the maker of Call of Duty, it said the move would give it the “building blocks for the metaverse.” It’s simpler than that.
